revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "The portion of a lake or ocean where less than 1% of sunlight penetrates" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|The portion of a lake or ocean where less than 1% of sunlight penetrates}} {{aquatic layer topics}} The '''aphotic zone''' (aphotic from [[Greek language|Greek]] prefix {{lang|grc|ἀ-}} + {{lang|grc|φῶς}} "without light") is the portion of a lake or ocean where there is little or no sunlight. It is formally defined as the depths beyond which less than 1% of sunlight penetrates. Consequently, [[bioluminescence]] is essentially the only light found in this zone. Most food in this zone comes from [[Marine snow|dead organisms sinking]] to the bottom of the lake or ocean from overlying waters.
The depth of the aphotic zone can be greatly affected by such things as [[turbidity]] and the season of the year. The aphotic zone underlies the [[photic zone]], which is that portion of a lake or ocean directly affected by sunlight.
==The ocean== Depending on how aphotic zone is defined, the aphotic zone of the ocean begins between depths of roughly {{convert|200|m|ft|abbr=on}} to {{convert|1000|m|ft|abbr=on}}, and extends to the ocean floor.<ref>{{Cite book |author1=Earle, Sylvia A. |author2=Thorne-Miller, Boyce | title=The living ocean: understanding and protecting marine biodiversity | year=1999 | publisher=Island Press | location=Washington, D.C. | isbn=1-55963-678-5 | pages=56–57}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | last=Kunich | first=John C. | title=Killing our oceans: dealing with the mass extinction of marine life | year=2006 | publisher=Praeger Publishers | location=Westport, CT | isbn=978-0-275-98878-4 | pages=8–9}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | last=Williams | first=Linda Meyer | title=Earth science demystified | year=2004 | publisher=McGraw-Hill | location=London | isbn=0-07-143499-2 | pages=287}}</ref> Temperatures can range from roughly {{convert|0|C|0}} to {{convert|6|C|0}}.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} Unusual and unique creatures dwell in this expanse of pitch black water, such as the [[Saccopharyngiformes|gulper eel]], the [[giant squid]], the [[anglerfish]], and the [[vampire squid]].
The aphotic zone is further divided into additional zones: the bathyal zone, the abyssal zone, and the hadal zone.<ref name=invitation>{{Cite book | last=Pinet | first=Paul R. | title=Invitation to Oceanography | date= | publisher=Jones & Bartlett Publishers | location= | isbn=0-7637-5993-7 | pages=294}}</ref> The bathyal zone extends from {{convert|200|m|0}} to {{convert|2000|m|0}}.<ref name=invitation /><ref>{{Cite book | last=Freiwald | first=Andre | title=Cold-Water Corals and Ecosystems (Erlangen Earth Conference Series) (Erlangen Earth Conference Series) | date= | publisher=Springer | location= | isbn=978-3-540-24136-2 | pages=980}}</ref> The abyssal zone extends from {{convert|2000|m|0}} to {{convert|6000|m|0}}.<ref name=invitation /> The hadal zone spans from depths of {{convert|6000|m|ft}} to the ocean floor.<ref name=invitation /> Creatures in these areas must be able to live in complete darkness.
==See also== * [[Abyssal zone]] * [[Benthic zone]] * [[Hadal zone]] * [[Pelagic zone]] * [[Photic zone]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Aphotic Zone}} [[Category:Aquatic ecology]] [[Category:Oceanography]]
{{ocean-stub}}

{{Other places|Ball Glacier (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox glacier | child = | name = Ball Glacier | other_name = | photo = James Ross Island group, northeastern Antarctic Peninsula. Image fusion of Landsat 8 OLI and Sentinel 1A SAR images.png | photo_width = | photo_alt = | photo_caption = James Ross Island group, northeastern Antarctic Peninsula | map = Antarctica | map_width = | map_alt = | map_caption = Location of Ball Glacier (James Ross Island) in [[Antarctica]] | mark = Blue_pog.svg | type = | location = [[James Ross Island]] | coordinates = {{coord|64|20|S|57|22|W|region:AQ|format=dms|display=inline}} | coords_ref = | area = | length = | width = | thickness = unknown | elevation_max = | elevation_min = | terminus = north-east to [[Markham Bay (Antarctica)]]
south-east side of [[James Ross Island]] | status = unknown | embedded = }} '''Ball Glacier''' is a small glacier separating [[Redshaw Point]] from [[Hamilton Point]], flowing north-east to [[Markham Bay (Antarctica)|Markham Bay]] on the south-east side of [[James Ross Island]]. It was named by the [[UK Antarctic Place-names Committee]] in 1995 after [[H. William Ball]] (b. 1926), Keeper of Paleontology, [[British Museum (Natural History)]], 1966–86, and author of [[Falklands Islands Dependencies Survey]] Scientific Report No. 24 on fossils from the James Ross Island area. ==See also== * [[List of glaciers in the Antarctic]] * [[Glaciology]] ==References== * {{usgs-gazetteer|id=17330|name=Ball Glacier}} {{coord|64|20|S|57|22|W|source:GNIS|display=title}} {{Portalbar|Antarctica|Geography}} {{Glaciers}} {{Glaciers in the Antarctic}} {{Glaciers of James Ross Island}} [[Category:Glaciers of James Ross Island]] {{JamesRossIsland-geo-stub}} {{Glaciology-stub}}

'''Batoni''' ({{lang-ka|ბატონი}}) is a [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] word for "[[lord]]", or "[[Master (form of address)|master]]". It is derived from ''patroni'' (პატრონი), the earlier term of similar meaning, and appears in common usage in the 15th century.
*In [[Feudalism in Georgia|Georgian feudal]] hierarchy, "batoni" may denote the supreme [[suzerain]] (i.e., [[monarch]]), [[Lord|seigneur]], or any secular or clerical who owned ''qma'', i.e., "[[slave]]" or "[[serf]]". The word sometimes appears as a part of the royal and nobiliary titulature. For example, the title of the Princes of [[Mukhrani]] was batoni ([[House of Mukhrani|Mukhran-batoni]]), and the early [[List of sovereigns of Kakheti#Kings of Kakheti|kings]] of [[Kingdom of Kakheti|Kakheti]] were likewise referred to by that title in some Georgian sources.<ref>[[Toumanoff, Cyril]] (1949–51). The Fifteenth-Century Bagratids and the Institution of Collegial Sovereignty in Georgia. ''Traditio'' 7: 216.</ref><ref>[[Stephen F. Jones|Jones, Stephen F.]] (2005), ''Socialism in Georgian Colors: The European Road to Social Democracy, 1883-1917'', p. 195. [[Harvard University Press]], {{ISBN|0-674-01902-4}}.</ref><ref name="Suny">[[Ronald Grigor Suny|Suny, Ronald Grigor]] (1994), ''The Making of the Georgian Nation'', pp. 42-3. [[Indiana University Press]], {{ISBN|0-253-20915-3}}</ref> *In modern usage, ''batoni'' is an [[honorific]] used for a [[man]], an equivalent of both [[Mr.]] and [[sir]]. The equivalent [[female]] title is ''k'albatoni'' (ქალბატონი). It can be used with the full name as well as either the last or first name. When addressing someone directly, the word is used in a [[vocative case]] ''(k'al)batono'' ([ქალ]ბატონო), and precedes either the first name (more commonly) or the last name, but it can also be used by itself in direct address.<ref>Braun, Friederike (1998), ''Terms of address: problems of patterns and usage in various languages and cultures'', pp. 106-113. Walter de Gruyter, {{ISBN|0-89925-432-2}}</ref>
== See also ==
*[[Batonishvili]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = Brian Wansink |image = BRIAN435S6556 copy.jpg |image_size = |caption = Wansink in 2007 |birth_date = |birth_place = [[Sioux City, Iowa]] |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = |alma_mater = [[Wayne State College]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]])
[[Drake University]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]])
[[Stanford University]] ([[Doctorate of Philosophy|PhD]]) |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = Food behavior and psychology |influences = |influenced = |signature = |footnotes = |ethnicity = |field = [[consumer behavior]], [[nutrition psychology]] |work_institutions = [[Cornell University]], [[University of Pennsylvania]], [[Dartmouth College]], [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] |prizes = [[Ig Nobel Prize]] (2007) |religion = }} '''Brian Wansink''' is an American former researcher and professor who worked in the fields of [[consumer behavior]] and [[marketing research]]. He is the former executive director of the [[USDA]]'s [[Center for Nutrition Policy and Promotion]] ([[CNPP]]) (2007–2009) and held the John S. Dyson Endowed Chair in the Applied Economics and Management Department at [[Cornell University]], where he directed the Cornell Food and Brand Lab.{{Cite web|url=http://publications.dyson.cornell.edu/vita/Wansink-vita.pdf|title=Wansink Vita|last=Wansink|first=Brian|date=June 7, 2017|website=Dyson Cornell SC Johnson School of Business|access-date=}} Wansink's lab researched people's food choices and ways to improve those choices. Starting in 2017, problems with Wansink's papers and presentations were brought to wider public scrutiny. These problems included conclusions not supported by the data presented, data and figures duplicated across papers, questionable data including [[GRIM test|impossible values]] and incorrect and inappropriate [[statistical analyses]], and data manipulation via "[[p-hacking]]". The lab had thirteen papers retracted (one twice) and had 15 corrections issued.{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Stephanie M.|title=Sliced And Diced: The Inside Story Of How An Ivy League Food Scientist Turned Shoddy Data Into Viral Studies|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/stephaniemlee/brian-wansink-cornell-p-hacking|work=BuzzFeed|date=February 25, 2018|language=en}} On September 20, 2018, Cornell determined that Wansink had committed scientific misconduct and removed him from research and teaching, limiting his activity to cooperating with further investigation of his papers; he resigned effective June 30, 2019.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180920200402/https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/stephaniemlee/brian-wansink-retired-cornell|title=Cornell Just Found Brian Wansink Guilty Of Scientific Misconduct And He Has Resigned|date=2018-09-20|access-date=2018-09-20}} == Early life and education == Brian Wansink was born in [[Sioux City, Iowa]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.healthcorps.org/staff/brian-wansink/|title=Brian Wansink Ph.D.|work=HealthCorps|access-date=2017-06-08|language=en-US}} He was raised in a blue-collar family and is the older brother of Craig Wansink,{{cite web |last1=Jenkins |first1=Robin Mather |title=The wizard of why |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2005-03-30/entertainment/0503300278_1_food-and-brand-lab-brian-wansink-food-psychologist |website=www.chicagotribune.com |publisher=Tribune Digital |accessdate=16 July 2018 |language=en |date=30 March 2005}} a professor and chair of the Department of Religious Studies at [[Virginia Wesleyan]].{{cite web|last1=Jiggetts|first1=Jennifer|title=Teaching, preaching: Norfolk man has two callings|url=https://pilotonline.com/news/article_6e581a4d-708d-5533-80f8-22a1e6475d28.html|website=Virginian-Pilot|accessdate=20 April 2018|language=en|date=27 November 2010}} Wansink received a B.S. in Business Administration from [[Wayne State College]] (Nebraska) in 1982 and an M.A. in Journalism and Mass Communication from [[Drake University]] in 1984, followed by a Ph.D. in Marketing (Consumer Behavior) in 1990 from [[Stanford Graduate School of Business]]. Wansink is married and has three daughters. His wife is a trained chef.{{cite web |last1=Butler |first1=Kiera |title=This fast-food-loving, organics-hating Ivy League prof will trick you into eating better |url=https://www.motherjones.com/environment/2015/03/brian-wansink-cornell-junk-food-health/ |website=Mother Jones |accessdate=16 July 2018 |date=March 2015}} ==Career== [[File:ConsumerCampKids.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Cornell Food and Brand Lab outreach]] Wansink's first academic appointment was to the faculty of the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College (1990–1994). He taught at the Wharton Graduate School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania (1995–1997), and was a marketing, nutritional science, advertising, and agricultural economics professor at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] (1997–2005) before moving to the Department of Applied Economics and Management in the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences at Cornell University in 2005. He set up a nonprofit foundation to support his work in 1999. Wansink's research focuses on ways people make choices – for example, how portion sizes affect food intake. Some of his work led to the introduction of mini-size packaging.{{cite news|last1=Severson|first1=Kim|title=Seduced by Snacks? No, Not You|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/11/dining/11snac.html |work=The New York Times|date=11 October 2006}} Another of his papers found that people who eat with someone who is fat will make worse food choices, which the UK NHS described as "not wholly convincing and does not prove this phenomenon exists in the general population."{{cite news|title=Behind the Headlines: Eating with a fat friend 'makes you eat more'|url=https://www.nhs.uk/news/food-and-diet/eating-with-a-fat-friend-makes-you-eat-more/|work=National Health Service|date=October 6, 2014}} In 2005, Wansink's lab published experimental findings in a paper titled, "Bottomless bowls: why visual cues of portion size may influence intake". In the "bottomless bowls study", an apparatus was built which contained a tube that pumped soup into the bottom of a bowl at a steady rate as the participant ate. Participants who ate from the bottomless bowl consumed more soup than those whose bowls were filled manually (thus were aware of the amount they consumed).{{Cite book |title=Associative learning and conditioning theory: human and non-human applications |last=Schachtman |first= Todd |last2=Reilly |first2=Steve |date=2011 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=9780199735969 |oclc=664352638}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/02/business/02leonhardt.html |title=Your Plate Is Bigger Than Your Stomach |last=Leonhardt |first=David |date=2007-05-02 |work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-06-26|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} In 2007, Wansink received the [[Ig Nobel Prize]] in [[Nutrition]] for the "bottomless bowls" study.{{cite news|title=Ig Nobel Prizes Stranger Than Fiction|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2007/10/ig-nobel-prizes-stranger-fiction|work=Science|date=5 October 2007|language=en}} The experiment's data and analysis were challenged as part of the review of Wansink's body of work that started in 2017.{{cite news|last1=Etchells|first1=Pete|last2=Chambers|first2=Chris|title=Mindless eating: is there something rotten behind the research?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/head-quarters/2018/feb/16/mindless-eating-brian-wansink-is-there-something-rotten-behind-the-research|work=the Guardian|date=16 February 2018|language=en}} In 2006, Wansink published ''Mindless Eating: Why We Eat More Than We Think''. It was described as a [[popular science]] book combined with a [[Self-help book|self-help diet book]], as each chapter ends with brief advice.{{cite news|last1=Ross|first1=Madeline K.B.|title=Why Do I Keep Super Sizing Me?|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2006/10/25/why-do-i-keep-super-sizing/|work=The Harvard Crimson|date=October 25, 2006|language=en}} The book details Wansink's research into what, how much, and when people eat.{{cite news|last1=Kennedy|first1=Jack L.|title=Joplin Independent: Mindless Eating is a nourishing read |url=http://www.joplinindependent.com/display_article.php/jkennedy1162333800 |work=Joplin Independent|date=October 31, 2006}} The book was cited by the [[National Action Against Obesity]] as being helpful in effort to curb [[obesity in the United States]].{{cite web|title=MeMe Roth And National Action Against Obesity Name 2006 Heroes and Villains in U.S. Fight Against Obesity|url=http://www.prweb.com//releases/obesity/trans-fat/prweb491541.htm |website=PRWeb |accessdate=1 April 2018|date=19 December 2006}} Wansink was appointed as the executive director of the [[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]]'s [[Center for Nutrition Policy and Promotion]] from November 2007 through January 2009. He was responsible for oversight of the 2010 Dietary Guidelines for Americans, [[MyPyramid.gov]], and various other food-related programs administered by the USDA.{{cite news|last1=Lang|first1=Susan S.|title=Wansink accepts 14-month appointment as executive director of USDA Center for Nutrition Policy and Promotion : Cornell Chronicle|url=http://news.cornell.edu/stories/2007/11/wansink-head-usda-center-nutrition-policy-and-promotion|work=Cornell Chronicle|date=November 20, 2007|language=en}} In 2011, Wansink was elected to a one-year-term as president of the [[Society for Nutrition Education]].{{cite web|title=Past Presidents|url=https://www.sneb.org/sneb-past-presidents/|publisher=SNEB|accessdate=18 March 2018}} In a 2009 paper, a team led by Wansink described their finding that calorie counts in ''[[The Joy of Cooking]]'' had gone up around 44% since the cookbook's first edition in 1936, and related this to the obesity epidemic. Over time this finding became a shorthand way to refer to the unhealthy [[western pattern diet]]. The publisher of ''Joy of Cooking'', John Becker, noticed that Wansink's sample size was small, consisting of only 18 recipes out of about 4500 that were published during the study time interval, and did his own analysis of changes in calories in the recipes. In 2017, after news of Wansink's research practices became widely discussed in the media, Becker sent his results to several statisticians, including James Heathers, a behavioral scientist at Northeastern University. Heathers found Wansink's conclusions to be invalid, and found a number of problems with Wansink's paper, including counting a whole cake as a "serving" and comparing a recipe for a clear chicken soup with one for [[gumbo]].{{cite news|last1=Rosner|first1=Helen|title=The Strange, Uplifting Tale of “Joy of Cooking” Versus the Food Scientist|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/annals-of-gastronomy/the-strange-uplifting-tale-of-joy-of-cooking-versus-the-food-scientist|work=New Yorker|date=21 March 2018}}{{cite news|last1=Resnick|first1=Brian|last2=Belluz|first2=Julia|title=Why the Joy of Cooking is going after a Cornell researcher|url=https://www.vox.com/science-and-health/2018/2/28/17061828/joy-of-cooking-brian-wansink-cornell-p-hacking|work=Vox|date=28 February 2018}} Wansink's second book, ''Slim by Design'' was released in 2014. During 2014 he ran a [[Kickstarter]] campaign and raised around $10,000 to fund a coaching program based on the book; as of February 2018 the program had not been produced.{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Stephanie|title=An Ivy League Scientist Raised $10,000 On Kickstarter For A Weight-Loss Program That Never Launched|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/stephaniemlee/brian-wansink-kickstarter-weight-loss|work=BuzzFeed|date=February 23, 2018|language=en}} Wansink's research came under scrutiny in 2017, leading to several retractions and an investigation by Cornell into the integrity of his work. In September 2018, Cornell determined that Wansink had committed scientific misconduct, and removed him from all teaching and research positions; he was restricted solely to cooperating with people investigating his publications. He also resigned from the university, effective June 30, 2019. After the announcement of the findings and his resignation, in an email exchange with ''Buzzfeed'', Wansink acknowledged some problems with his published work and also wrote: "There was no fraud, no intentional misreporting, no plagiarism, or no misappropriation." == Retractions and corrections == ===Pizza papers=== [[File:Xkcd-significant-panel.png||thumb|right|Panel from a 2011 ''[[xkcd]]'' cartoon explaining [[p hacking]], in which scientists look for relationships between many colors of jelly beans and acne, and find a p value <0.05 only for green ones.{{cite web|title=Significant|url=https://xkcd.com/882/|publisher=xkcd|date=2011-04-06}}

Cited in New York Magazine piece about Wansink lab's p hacking.]] In January 2017, the validity of research from Wansink's labs was called into question by Jordan Anaya, Nicholas J L Brown, and Tim van der Zee, after Wansink had written a blog post about asking a graduate student to "salvage" conclusions from a study which had [[null result]]s, subsequently producing five papers from it, all published with Wansink as co-author.{{cite news|last1=O'Grady|first1=Cathleen|title=“Mindless Eating,” or how to send an entire life of research into question|url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2017/04/the-peer-reviewed-saga-of-mindless-eating-mindless-research-is-bad-too/|work=Ars Technica|date=24 April 2017|language=en-us}} Van der Zee, Anaya, and Brown analysed four of the five papers (referred to as "the pizza papers"), and found conclusions not supported by the data presented, and a total of 150 questionable numbers, such as [[GRIM test|impossible values]], incorrect [[ANOVA]] results, and dubious [[p-value]]s. According to the critics, requests for access to the original data were denied by Wansink, who cited privacy issues over the anonymity of the participants. A February 2017 article in ''[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]'' described the pizza papers as "shockingly unprofessional" and expressed concern over the journals that published them.{{Cite news|url=http://nymag.com/scienceofus/2017/02/cornells-food-and-brand-lab-has-a-major-problem.html|title=A Popular Diet-Science Lab Has Been Publishing Really Shoddy Research|last=Singal|first=Jesse|date=2017-02-08|work=|newspaper=New York magazine|access-date=2017-02-20|language=en|via=}} In response, Wansink announced an in-depth review of the four disputed papers, after locating some of the original datasets,{{cite news|last1=Bartlett|first1=Tom|title=Spoiled Science|url=https://www.chronicle.com/article/Spoiled-Science/239529|work=The Chronicle of Higher Education|date=17 March 2017}} and published a detailed response in March 2017. A few days later, Cornell released a statement confirming that the university administration had conducted a preliminary investigation of Wansink's four pizza papers, and had not found evidence of scientific misconduct. The investigation did find multiple cases of [[self-plagiarism]] and confirmed "numerous instances of inappropriate data handling and statistical analysis", requiring Wansink to hire independent, external statistical experts to check and reanalyze his own review of the papers.{{cite web |title=Cornell University Statement Regarding Questions About Professor Brian Wansink's Research {{!}} Cornell Chronicle |url=http://news.cornell.edu/media-relations/advisories/cornell-university-statement-regarding-questions-about-professor-brian |website=news.cornell.edu |accessdate=16 July 2018 |language=en |date=7 April 2017}} ===Further corrections and retractions follow=== Later in 2017, Anaya and his colleagues found errors in six other papers published by members of the Cornell Food and Brand Lab. As of December 2017, six papers had been retracted and 14 corrections had been issued.{{cite news|title=Another retraction to appear for Cornell food scientist Brian Wansink|url=https://retractionwatch.com/2017/12/28/another-retraction-appear-cornell-food-scientist-brian-wansink/|work=Retraction Watch|date=28 December 2017}} By March 2018, two more papers had been retracted and an additional correction made, bringing the totals to 7 (one of them retracted twice, so technically 8) and 15, respectively.{{cite news|title=Caught Our Notice: Retraction eight as errors in Wansink paper are “too voluminous” for a correction|url=https://retractionwatch.com/2018/03/19/caught-our-notice-retraction-eight-as-errors-in-wansink-paper-are-too-voluminous-for-a-correction/|work=Retraction Watch|date=19 March 2018}} In April 2018, ''[[JAMA (journal)|JAMA]] (Journal of the American Medical Association)'' issued a "Notice of Expression of Concern" about all six articles authored by Wansink in JAMA and JAMA network specialty journals, to alert the scientific community of concerns about the validity of Wansink's research; the notice included a request for Cornell to have the validity of the papers independently assessed.{{Cite journal| last=Bauchner |first=Howard |title=Expression of Concern: Wansink B, Cheney MM. Super Bowls: Serving Bowl Size and Food Consumption. JAMA 2005; 293(14):1727-1728 |url=https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2678649 |journal=JAMA |volume=319 |issue=18 |pages=1869 |language=en |doi=10.1001/jama.2018.4908|pmid=29710107 |year=2018 }} In September 2018 JAMA retracted six papers by Wansink.{{cite news |title=JAMA journals retract six papers by food marketing researcher Brian Wansink |url=https://retractionwatch.com/2018/09/19/jama-journals-retract-six-papers-by-food-marketing-researcher-brian-wansink/ |work=Retraction Watch |date=19 September 2018}} The following papers were retracted:{{cite web|title=Retraction Watch Database: Wansink|url=http://retractiondatabase.org/(X(1)S(ll31ceb4btar0pwmkmgazxtg))/RetractionSearch.aspx?AspxAutoDetectCookieSupport=1#?AspxAutoDetectCookieSupport%3d1%26auth%3dWansink%252c%2bBrian|accessdate=18 March 2018}}{{cite news|title=Retract, replace, retract: Beleaguered food researcher pulls article from JAMA journal (again)|url=https://retractionwatch.com/2017/10/20/retract-replace-retract-beleaguered-food-researcher-pulls-article-jama-journal/|work=Retraction Watch|date=20 October 2017}} * {{cite journal|last1=Wansink|first1=Brian|last2=Park|first2=Se-Bum|title=Retracted: Sensory Suggestiveness and Labeling: Do Soy Labels Bias Taste?|journal=Journal of Sensory Studies|date=November 2002|volume=17|issue=5|pages=483–491|doi=10.1111/j.1745-459X.2002.tb00360.x}} ::{{cite journal|title=Retraction Statement: 'Sensory suggestiveness and labeling: Do soy labels bias taste?' by B. Wansink and S.-B. Park|journal=Journal of Sensory Studies|date=April 2017|volume=32|issue=2|pages=e12259|doi=10.1111/joss.12259}} * {{cite journal|last1=Wansink|first1=Brian|last2=Westgren|first2=Randall|title=RETRACTED: Profiling taste-motivated segments|journal=Appetite|date=December 2003|volume=41|issue=3|pages=323–327|doi=10.1016/S0195-6663(03)00120-X}} * {{cite journal|last1=Wansink|first1=Brian|last2=Just|first2=David R.|last3=Payne|first3=Collin R.|title=Can Branding Improve School Lunches?|journal=Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine|date=1 October 2012|volume=166|issue=10|pages=1–2|doi=10.1001/archpediatrics.2012.999|pmid=22911396}} (retracted and republished then retracted again) ::{{cite journal|last1=Wansink|first1=Brian|last2=Just|first2=David R.|last3=Payne|first3=Collin R.|title=Notice of Retraction and Replacement. Wansink B, Just DR, Payne CR. Can Branding Improve School Lunches? 2012;166(10):967-968. doi: 10.1001/archpediatrics.2012.999|journal=JAMA Pediatrics|date=21 September 2017|doi=10.1001/jamapediatrics.2017.3136}} :::{{cite journal|last1=Wansink|first1=Brian|last2=Just|first2=David R.|last3=Payne|first3=Collin R.|title=Notice of Retraction. Wansink B, Just DR, Payne CR. Can Branding Improve School Lunches? 2012;166(10):967-968|journal=JAMA Pediatrics|date=1 December 2017|volume=171|issue=12|pages=1230|doi=10.1001/jamapediatrics.2017.4603|pmid=29053760}} * {{cite journal|last1=Wansink|first1=Brian|last2=Just|first2=David R.|last3=Payne|first3=Collin R.|last4=Klinger|first4=Matthew Z.|title=RETRACTED: Attractive names sustain increased vegetable intake in schools|journal=Preventive Medicine|date=October 2012|volume=55|issue=4|pages=330–332|doi=10.1016/j.ypmed.2012.07.012|pmid=22846502}} * {{cite television content increases food intake. |journal=JAMA Internal Medicine |date=November 2014 |volume=174 |issue=11 |pages=1842–3 |doi=10.1001/jamainternmed.2014.4098 |pmid=25179157}} * {{cite journal |doi=10.1001/jamapediatrics.2013.82 |pmid=23645188}} == Books == * {{cite book|last1=Sudman|first1=Seymour|last2=Wansink|first2=Brian|title=Consumer Panels|date=2002|publisher=American Marketing Association|location=Chicago, Ill.|isbn=978-0-87757-297-8|edition=2nd}} * {{cite book|last1=Bradburn,|first1=Norman M.|last2=Sudman|first2=Seymour|last3=Wansink|first3=Brian|title=Asking Questions : the definitive guide to questionnaire design for market research, political polls, and social and health questionnaires|date=2004|publisher=Jossey-Bass|location=San Francisco|isbn=978-0-7879-7088-8|edition=Rev.}} * {{cite book|last1=Wansink|first1=Brian|title=Marketing Nutrition : soy, functional foods, biotechnology, and obesity|date=2004|publisher=University of Illinois Press|location=Urbana, Ill.|isbn=978-0-252-02942-4|edition=First Illinois paperback}} * {{cite book|last1=Wansink|first1=Brian|title=Mindless Eating : why we eat more than we revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Chanda Prescod-Weinstein | image = | caption = Chanda Prescod-Weinstein | birth_date = | birth_place = [[El Sereno, Los Angeles|El Sereno]], [[Los Angeles]], U.S. | alma_mater = [[Harvard College]]
[[University of Waterloo]]
[[University of California, Santa Cruz]] | workplaces = [[Goddard Space Flight Center]]
[[MIT]]
[[University of Washington]] | fields = [[Cosmology]]
[[Quantum gravity]]
Equality activism }} '''Chanda Prescod-Weinstein''' is an American [[cosmologist]], science writer and equality activist based at the [[University of Washington]]. She is the Principal Investigator on a [[Foundational Questions Institute]] (FQXI) grant titled "Epistemological Schemata of Astro | Physics: A Reconstruction of Observers". == Early life and education == Prescod-Weinstein was born in [[El Sereno, Los Angeles|El Sereno]] in East Los Angeles, California, and went to school in the [[Los Angeles Unified School District]].{{Cite journal|last=Prescod-Weinstein|first= Chanda Rosalyn Sojourner|date=2010-09-22|title=Cosmic Acceleration As Quantum Gravity Phenomenology|url=https://uwspace.uwaterloo.ca/handle/10012/5498?show=full|publisher=UWSpace|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/chanda-prescod-weinstein_n_7574020|title=Meet The 63rd Black Woman In American History With A Physics Ph.D.|first=Nico|last=Pitney|date=2015-06-24|work=[[HuffPost UK]]|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-GB}} She earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in Physics and Astronomy at [[Harvard College]] in 2003. Her thesis, "A study of winds in active galactic nuclei", was completed under the supervision of Martin Elvis.{{Cite journal|last=Prescod-Weinstein|first=Chanda|date=2018-02-06|title=A study of winds in active galactic nuclei /|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/33760463_A_study_of_winds_in_active_galactic_nuclei}} She then earned a Master's degree in Astronomy at the [[University of California, Santa Cruz]], working with [[Anthony Aguirre]].{{Cite web|url=http://backreaction.blogspot.co.uk/2007/01/guest-post-chanda.html|title=Guest Post: Chanda|website=backreaction.blogspot.co.uk|access-date=2018-02-06}} In 2010, Prescod-Weinstein completed her [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] dissertation, titled "Acceleration as [[Phenomenological quantum gravity|Quantum Gravity Phenomenology]]",[https://www.worldcat.org/title/cosmic-acceleration-as-quantum-gravity-phenomenology/oclc/827751865&referer=brief_results "Cosmic acceleration as quantum gravity phenomenology"], WorldCat. under the supervision of [[Lee Smolin]] and Niayesh Afshordi at [[University of Waterloo]], while conducting her research at the [[Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.perimeterinstitute.ca/people/chanda-prescod-weinstein|title=Chanda Prescod-Weinstein {{!}} Perimeter Institute|website=www.perimeterinstitute.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-02-15}} In doing so, she became the 63rd African-American woman in history to earn a Ph.D. in Physics.{{Cite web|url=http://aawip.com/|title=AAWIP|website=aawip.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-06}} == Research == Prescod-Weinstein's research has focused on various topics in [[Physical cosmology|cosmology]] and [[theoretical physics]], including the [[axion]] as a [[dark matter]] candidate,{{Cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn28632-tiny-dark-matter-stars-would-harbour-particles-that-act-as-one/|title=Tiny dark matter stars would harbour particles that act as one|work=New Scientist|first=Anna|last= Nowogrodzki|date= 2015-12-07|access-date=2018-02-09|language=en-US}} [[Inflation (cosmology)|inflation]], and [[Classical field theory|classical]] and [[Quantum field theory|quantum fields]] in the [[Chronology of the universe|early universe]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.perimeterinstitute.ca/videos/meet-scientist-chanda-prescod-weinstein|title=Meet a Scientist - Chanda Prescod-Weinstein {{!}} Perimeter Institute|website=www.perimeterinstitute.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-02-06}} From 2004 to 2007 Prescod-Weinstein was a named [[National Science Foundation]] Graduate Research Fellow. After Prescod-Weinstein's Ph.D., she was a NASA Postdoctoral Fellow in the Observational Cosmology Lab at [[Goddard Space Flight Center]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.cprescodweinstein.com/curriculum-vitae/|title=Curriculum Vitae|website=Chanda Prescod-Weinstein, PhD|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-06}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.perimeterinstitute.ca/people/chanda-prescod-weinstein|title=Chanda Prescod-Weinstein {{!}} Perimeter Institute|website=www.perimeterinstitute.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-02-06}} In 2011, she won a Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Postdoctoral Fellowship at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], where she was jointly appointed to the Kavli Institute for Astrophysics and Space Research and the Department of Physics.{{Cite web|url=http://mlkscholars.mit.edu/cprescod-weinstein/|title=Chanda Prescod-Weinstein, Physics – Martin Luther King Jr. Scholars|website=mlkscholars.mit.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-06}} At [[MIT]], Prescod-Weinstein worked in [[Alan Guth]]'s group in the Centre for Theoretical Physics.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cprescodweinstein.com/how-i-got-here-1/|title=How I Got Here|website=Chanda Prescod-Weinstein, PhD|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-06}} In 2016, she became the Principal Investigator on a $100,522 [[FQXI]] grant to study “Epistemological Schemata of Astro | Physics: A Reconstruction of Observers” seeking to answer questions regarding how to re-frame who is an "observer", to acknowledge those existing outside of the European Enlightenment framework, and how that might change knowledge production in science.{{Cite web|url=https://fqxi.org/grants/large/awardees/view/__details/2016/prescod-weinstein|title=FQXi - Foundational Questions Institute|website=fqxi.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-28}} She is working on the NASA STROBE-X experiment.{{Cite web|url=https://kipac.stanford.edu/events/making-universe-axions|title=Making a Universe with Axions {{!}} Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology (KIPAC)|website=kipac.stanford.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-02-06}} == Awards == Prescod-Weinstein earned the Barbados House Canada Inc. Gordon C Bynoe Scholarship in 2007. In 2013 she won the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] "Infinite Kilometer Award".{{Cite web|url=http://science.mit.edu/policies/sos-staff-infinite-k-award-previous-winners|title=MIT School of Science|website=science.mit.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-02-06}} In March 2017, Prescod-Weinstein won the LGBT+ Physicists Acknowledgement of Excellence Award ''"For Years of Dedicated Effort in Changing Physics Culture to be More Inclusive and Understanding Toward All Marginalised Peoples".''{{Cite web|url=http://lgbtphysicists.org/excellence.html|title=lgbt+physicists - Acknowledgement of Excellence Awards|website=lgbtphysicists.org|access-date=2018-02-06}} == Public engagement == Prescod-Weinstein is an advocate{{Cite news|url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/how-can-we-give-black-and-latino-astronomers-foundation-reach-stars-180960213/|title=Why the Universe Needs More Black and Latino Astronomers|last=Sokol|first=Joshua|work=Smithsonian|date= 2016-08-23|access-date=2018-02-09|language=en}} for increasing the diversity within science by considering [[intersectionality]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/speaking-of-science/wp/2017/07/11/women-of-color-face-staggering-harassment-in-space-science/|title=Women of color face staggering harassment in space science|last=Kaplan|first=Sarah|date=2017-07-11|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-02-09|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} and proper celebration of the underrepresented groups who contribute to scientific knowledge production.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1003680291|title=Hidden Human Computers: The Black Women of NASA|last=Bradford.|first=Edwards, Sue|publisher=ABDO Digital|isbn=1680797409|location=New York|oclc=1003680291}} She has been a member of the executive committee of the [[National Society of Black Physicists]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.preposterousuniverse.com/blog/2006/10/22/guest-post-chanda-prescod-weinstein/|title=Guest Post: Chanda Prescod-Weinstein|date=2006-10-22|work=Sean Carroll|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US}} In 2017 she was a plenary speaker at the Women in Physics Canada meeting.{{Cite web|last=Institute for Quantum Computing|title=Chanda Prescod-Weinstein - Fields of Cosmological Dreams|date=2017-08-15|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bAqseJNNC7E&feature=youtu.be|access-date=2018-02-06}} Prescod-Weinstein has contributed popular science articles for ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', ''[[American Scientist]]'', ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature Astronomy]]'', ''[[Bitch (magazine)|Bitch media]]'', and ''[[Physics World]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cprescodweinstein.com/writing/|title=Writing for the Public|website=Chanda Prescod-Weinstein, PhD|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-06}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/science/2017/08/evolutionary_psychology_is_the_most_obvious_example_of_how_science_is_flawed.html|title=Stop Equating 'Science' With Truth|last=Prescod-Weinstein|first=Chanda|date=2017-08-09|work=Slate|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US|issn=1091-2339}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.americanscientist.org/blog/macroscope/scientists-must-challenge-what-makes-studies-scientific|title=Scientists Must Challenge What Makes Studies Scientific|first=Chanda|last=Prescod-Weinstein|date=2017-08-14|work=American Scientist|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en}}{{Cite journal|last=Prescod-Weinstein|first=Chanda|date=|title=Curiosity and the end of discrimination|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41550-017-0145|journal=Nature Astronomy|language=En|volume=1|issue=6|pages=|doi=10.1038/s41550-017-0145|issn=2397-3366|via=|bibcode=2017NatAs...1E.145P}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.bitchmedia.org/profile/dr-chanda-prescod-weinstein|title=Dr. Chanda Prescod-Weinstein {{!}} Bitch Media|website=www.bitchmedia.org|language=en|access-date=2018-02-08}} She is on the Book Review Board of ''[[Physics Today]]'' and editor-in-chief of The Offing.{{Cite web|url=https://roommagazine.com/interview/litmaglove-offings-chanda-prescod-weinstein|title=#LitMagLove: The Offing's Chanda Prescod-Weinstein {{!}} Room Magazine|website=roommagazine.com|first=Rachel |last=Thompson|language=en|access-date=2018-02-06}} The [[American Physical Society]] described her as a "vocal presence on Twitter".{{Cite web|url=https://www.aps.org/publications/apsnews/updates/huffpost.cfm|title=APS Member Chanda Prescod-Weinstein Gets the HuffPo Treatment|website=www.aps.org|language=en|date= 2015-07-06|access-date=2018-02-06}} Prescod-Weinstein maintains a "Decolonising Science Reading List.{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@chanda/decolonising-science-reading-list-339fb773d51f|title=Decolonising Science Reading List|last=Prescod-Weinstein|first=Chanda|date=2015-04-25|website=Chanda Prescod-Weinstein|access-date=2018-02-06}} Prescod-Weinstein has given several interviews and public talks.{{Cite news|url=http://www.sparkpluglabs.co/awesome-woman/chanda-prescod-weinstein|title=Chanda Prescod-Weinstein, PhD: A day in the life of an astrophysicist|work=Spark Plug Labs|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cprescodweinstein.com/speaking/|title=Speaker|website=Chanda Prescod-Weinstein, PhD|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-06}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cprescodweinstein.com/profiles|title=In the News|website=Chanda Prescod-Weinstein, PhD|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-06}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.nylon.com/articles/black-women-in-academia|title=10 Black Women in Academia That You Need To Know About|first=Isabel|last=Calkins|date=2017-02-06|work=[[Nylon (magazine)|NYLON]]|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en}} In 2018, Prescod-Weinstein published "Particles for Justice", a statement condemning [[Alessandro Strumia]]'s controversial comments on women in physics at [[CERN]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.particlesforjustice.org/|title=Home|website=Particles for Justice|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-12}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/story/physicists-condemn-sexism-through-particles-for-justice/|title=Physicists Condemn Sexism Through ‘Particles for Justice’|work=WIRED|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://physicsworld.com/a/thousands-of-physicists-sign-letter-condemning-disgraceful-alessandro-strumia-gender-talk/|title=Thousands of physicists sign letter condemning 'disgraceful' Alessandro Strumia gender talk – Physics World|date=2018-10-08|work=Physics World|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en-GB}}. == Personal life == Prescod-Weinstein is queer and agender. She is married to a lawyer. == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.cprescodweinstein.com/}} *{{Twitter | IBJIYONGI | Dr. Chanda Prescod-Weinstein }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Prescod-Weinstein, Chanda}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Astrophysics]] [[Category:Cosmologists]] [[Category:Theoretical physicists]] [[Category:American astrophysicists]] [[Category:American astronomers]] [[Category:African-American scientists]] [[Category:Jewish American scientists]] [[Category:Science writers]] [[Category:American science writers]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:University of California, Santa Cruz]] [[Category:Minority rights activists]] [[Category:American human rights activists]] [[Category:Genderqueer people]] [[Category:LGBT scientists from the United States]] [[Category:LGBT writers from the United States]] [[Category:LGBT people from California]] [[Category:LGBT African Americans]] [[Category:Queer writers]] [[Category:LGBT academics]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

{{Infobox journal | title = Child Abuse Review | cover = | discipline = [[Social work]] | abbreviation = Child Abuse Rev. | editor = Jane V. Appleton
Peter Sidebotham | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]] | country = [[United Kingdom]] | frequency = Bimonthly | history = 1992–present | impact = 1.543 | impact-year = 2016 | website = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/%28ISSN%291099-0852 | link1 = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/%28ISSN%291099-0852 | link1-name = Online access | link2 = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/%28ISSN%291099-0852/issues | link2-name = Online archive | ISSN = 0952-9136 | eISSN = 1099-0852 | OCLC = 225105359 | LCCN = 93643754 | CODEN = CABEEB }} '''''Child Abuse Review''''' is a bimonthly [[peer-reviewed]] academic journal with a focus on child protection, particularly: research findings, practice developments, training initiatives and policy issues. It is also the official journal of [[British Association for the Study and Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect|British Association for the Study and Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect (BASPCAN)]].{{cite web |title=Child Abuse Review: about this journal: Overview | url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/%28ISSN%291099-0852/homepage/ProductInformation.html |publisher= [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]] |accessdate= 10 September 2015 }} It is co-edited by Jane V. Appleton ([[Oxford Brookes University]]), and Peter Sidebotham ([[Warwick Medical School|University of Warwick]]).{{cite web |title=Child Abuse Review: about this journal: Editorial board | url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/%28ISSN%291099-0852/homepage/EditorialBoard.html |publisher= [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]] |accessdate= 10 September 2015 }} According to the ''[[Journal Citation Reports]]'', the journal has a 2016 [[impact factor]] of 1.543, ranking it 9th out of 42 journals in the category "Social Work" and 19th out of 43 journals in the category "Family Studies".{{cite book |year=2017 |chapter=Journals Ranked by Impact: Social Work and Family Studies |title=2016 [[Journal Citation Reports]] |publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] |edition=Social Sciences |series=[[Web of Science]]}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{Official|http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/%28ISSN%291099-0852}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Child Abuse Review}} [[Category:Bimonthly journals]] [[Category:English-language journals]] [[Category:Publications established in 1992]] [[Category:Wiley-Blackwell academic journals]] [[Category:Sociology journals]] {{Social-science-journal-stub}}

revision.comment: disambiguate [[RPM]] with direct link to [[revolutions per minute]] (via JWB)
revision.text:
In [[centrifugation]] the '''clearing factor''' or '''k factor''' represents the relative pelleting efficiency of a given centrifuge rotor at maximum rotation speed. It can be used to estimate the time <math>t</math> (in hours) required for [[sedimentation]] of a fraction with a known [[sedimentation coefficient]] <math>s</math> (in [[svedberg]]s):
: <math>t = \frac{k}{s} </math>
The value of the clearing factor depends on the maximum [[angular velocity]] <math>\omega</math> of a centrifuge (in rad/s) and the minimum and maximum [[radius]] <math>r</math> of the [[Turbine|rotor]]:
: <math>k = \frac{\ln(r_{\rm{max}} / r_{\rm{min}})}{\omega^2} \times \frac{10^{13}}{3600}</math>
As the rotational speed of a centrifuge is usually specified in [[revolutions per minute|RPM]], the following formula is often used for convenience:<ref>[http://www.coleparmer.com/techinfo/techinfo.asp?htmlfile=basic-centrifugation.htm&ID=30 "Basics of Centrifugation"]</ref>
: <math>k = \frac{2.53 \cdot 10^5 \times \ln(r_{\rm{max}} / r_{\rm{min}})}{(\rm{RPM}/1000)^2}</math>
[[Centrifuge]] manufacturers usually specify the minimum, maximum and average radius of a rotor, as well as the <math>k</math> factor of a centrifuge-rotor combination.
For runs with a rotational speed lower than the maximum rotor-speed, the <math>k</math> factor has to be adjusted:
: <math>k_{\rm{adj}} = k \left( \frac{\mbox{maximum rotor-speed}}{\mbox{actual rotor-speed}} \right)</math><sup>2</sup>
The K-factor is related to the sedimentation coefficient <math>S</math> by the formula:
<math>T = \frac{K}{S}</math>
Where <math>T</math> is the time to pellet a certain particle in hours. Since <math>S</math> is a constant for a certain particle, this relationship can be used to interconvert between different rotors.
<math> \frac{T_1}{K_1} = \frac{T_2}{K_2}</math>
Where <math>T_1</math> is the time to pellet in one rotor, and <math>K_1</math> is the K-factor of that rotor. <math>K_2</math> is the K-factor of the other rotor, and <math>T_2</math>, the time to pellet in the other rotor, can be calculated. In this manner, one does not need access to the exact rotor cited in a protocol, as long as the K-factor can be calculated. [http://www.google.com/search?q=centrifuge%20calculator Many online calculators] are available to perform the calculations for common rotors.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.beckman.com/centrifugation/rotors-tubes-adapters/rotors Beckman Coulter lab resources] and manuals * [http://homepages.gac.edu/~cellab/appds/appd-f.html Appendix F] of the [http://homepages.gac.edu/~cellab/index-1.html Cell Biology Laboratory Manual]
[[Category:Laboratory techniques]] [[Category:Unit operations]]
{{fluiddynamics-stub}}

{{Multiple issues|{{notability|1=Academics|date=March 2017}}{{BLP sources|date=March 2017}}{{Third-party|date=March 2017}}}}
'''Colin Eden''' was a professor in [[management science]] and [[operations research]] at [[Strathclyde University]].<ref name="Colin_Retires">{{cite web |url=https://www.sbs.strath.ac.uk/feeds/news.aspx?id=519 |title=Professor Colin Eden retires |accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref>
== Academic career ==
Eden worked as an operational researcher in engineering upon bagging a [[doctorate]]. He then proceeded to academia, first working at the [[University of Bath]] Management School as a senior lecturer, then, as a reader.<ref name="Colin_Retires"/>
He then assumed a professorship at [[Strathclyde University]] in [[management science]]. He subsequently became head of department at the Strathclyde Business School. And then Director of the Graduate School of Business at Strathclyde, and then finally Vice Dean.<ref name="Colin_Retires"/>
His research interests is in business strategy, [[project management]], and operations research.<ref name="Google_Scholar">{{cite web |url=https://scholar.google.co.uk/citations?user=iEYUdaYAAAAJ |title=Google Scholar Page |accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref>
He is widely published in respected management, project management and management science journals such as: [[Journal of Management Studies]]; and [[European Journal of Operational Research]]. His significant contributions are i) in the development of SODA as a problem structuring method; setting out a clear view of the nature Action Research in the study of management and organisations; iii) the development and theoretical grounding for strategy development as negotiation.
He has been awarded many accolades including lifetime achievement awards from the OR Society (Beale Medal 2007)and from INFORMS GND Section (2008).
== Select Publications ==
* Eden, C., 1995. Strategic options development and analysis (SODA) * {{cite journal|author= Colin Eden|year=1988|title= Cognitive mapping|url= http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0377221788900021|journal= [[European Journal of Operational Research]]|volume=36|issue=1|pages= 1–13|doi= 10.1016/0377-2217(88)90002-1|ref=harv|postscript=.}} * Eden, C., Ackermann, F. and Cropper, S., 1992. [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-6486.1992.tb00667.x/full The analysis of cause maps]. [[Journal of Management Studies]], 29(3), pp. 309–324. [[Digital object identifier|doi]]: [http://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-6486.1992.tb00667.x 10.1111/j.1467-6486.1992.tb00667.x] * Eden, C., 1992. [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-6486.1992.tb00664.x/full On the nature of cognitive maps]. [[Journal of Management Studies]], 29(3), pp. 261–265. [[Digital object identifier|doi]]: [http://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-6486.1992.tb00664.x 10.1111/j.1467-6486.1992.tb00664.x] * Eden, Colin and Ackermann, Fran., 1998. Making Strategy: The Journey of Strategic Management. London: Sage. * Eden, C.; Ackermann, F., and Williams, T. The Amoebic Growth of Project Costs. Project Management Journal. 2005; 36(2):15-27. * Eden, C. and Huxham, C., 2006. Researching Organizations Using Action Research. Clegg, S.; Hardy, C., and Nord, W., Eds. Handbook of Organization Studies. Beverly Hills: Sage; pp. 388–408. * Ackermann, Fran and Eden, Colin., 2011. Making Strategy: Mapping Out Strategic Success. London: Sage.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links ==
* [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TF-brG_Y108 Introduction to Making Strategy]

{{Infobox military person |name = David M. Jones |image = David M. Jones DoolittleRaiders Crew5.jpg |image_size = 250 |caption = David M. Jones, 1942 |birth_date = {{Birth date |1913|12|18}} |death_date = {{Death date and age|2008|11|25|1913|12|18}} |placeofburial_label = |birth_place = [[Marshfield, Oregon]] |death_place = [[Tucson, Arizona]] |placeofburial = |nickname = |allegiance={{flag|United States of America}} |branch = [[File:Seal of the US Air Force.svg|25px]] [[United States Air Force]] |serviceyears = 1936–1973 |rank = [[File:US-O8 insignia.svg|25px]] [[Major general (United States)|Major General]] |unit = [[17th Bombardment Group]] ("[[Doolittle Raid]]ers") |commands = |battles = {{plainlist| *[[World War II]] *:[[Doolittle Raid]] }} |awards = {{plainlist| *[[Air Force Distinguished Service Medal|Distinguished Service Medal]] *[[Legion of Merit]] *[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] (2) *[[Purple Heart]] }} |relations = |laterwork = }} '''David M. Jones''' (December 18, 1913 – November 25, 2008) was a [[United States Air Force]] pilot and general officer who served with distinction during [[World War II]]. He was one of the [[Doolittle Raid]]ers whose exploits in April 1942 were dramatized in the film ''[[Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo]]''. He then flew combat missions over North Africa, where he was shot down. He was a German prisoner of war for two and a half years — helping with the April 1944 mass escape at [[Stalag Luft III]] .<ref name=ArizonaStarDaily_Sottosanti_20081130/>
In his last assignment with the Air Force, Jones was the commander of the Air Force Eastern Test Range in [[Cape Canaveral|Cape Kennedy]], Florida as well as the [[U.S. Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] Manager for Manned Space Flight Support Operations. He retired from the Air Force in 1973.
==Early years; education== David Mudgett Jones was born on December 18, 1913 in [[Marshfield, Oregon]], the son of David Arthur (Dade) Jones and Grace Mudgett. His father Dade Jones, the son of Welsh immigrants, homesteaded land in Meadow Lake Township, North Dakota in 1896 before marrying Grace and moving to Oregon.
David Jones enlisted in the [[Arizona National Guard]] while he was attending the [[University of Arizona]] at [[Tucson, Arizona|Tucson]], from 1932 to 1936. His later education included three major [[U.S. military|Armed Forces]] schools: [[Command and General Staff School]] in [[Fort Leavenworth]], Kansas, 1946; [[Armed Forces Staff College]] in [[Norfolk, Virginia]], 1948; and the [[National War College]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], 1956.
Jones was [[Commissioned officer|commissioned]] a [[US Second Lieutenant|second lieutenant]] in the [[U.S. Cavalry]] arm of the [[Arizona Army National Guard]], where he served one year of active duty before transferring to the [[United States Army Air Corps|Army Air Corps]] and entering pilot training in June 1937. After earning his [[U.S. Air Force aeronautical rating|wings]] in June 1938, he served as a [[Northrop A-17]] pilot with the [[95th Reconnaissance Squadron|95th Attack Squadron]] of the [[17th Bombardment Group|17th Attack Group]], based at [[March Air Reserve Base|March Field]], California.
In 1939 the 17th was re-designated a medium bombardment group and transferred to [[McChord Air Force Base|McChord Field]], Washington. By September 1941 it became the first unit of the [[United States Army Air Forces|Army Air Forces]] to be fully equipped with the new [[North American B-25 Mitchell|B-25 Mitchell]] medium bomber.
==World War II==
===Doolittle Raid=== [[File:DoolittleRaiders Crew5 060217-F-1234P-113 1.jpg|180px|thumb|right|Doolittle Raider Crew No. 5: Front row: '''Capt. David M. Jones''', pilot; Lt. Rodney R. Wilder, copilot; back row: Lt. Eugene F. McGurl, navigator; Lt. [[Denver V. Truelove]], bombardier; Sgt. Joseph W. Manske, flight engineer/gunner.]] In early 1942, Jones volunteered for the Doolittle Project — a secret bombing raid to be launched on Japan in retaliation for the December 1941 [[attack on Pearl Harbor]].<ref name=AFLink_20081202>{{cite news |accessdate=December 2, 2008 |url=http://www.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123126260 |title=Airmen bid farewell to two Doolittle Raiders |date=December 2, 2008 |work=Air Force Link |publisher=United States Air Force |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121212025453/http://www.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123126260 |archivedate=December 12, 2012 |df= }}</ref> During the training phase of this project, he acted as navigation and intelligence officer for the ad hoc squadron of B-25 bombers. On April 18, 1942, the [[Doolittle Raid]] launched from the [[United States Navy]]'s aircraft carrier {{USS|Hornet|CV-8}}, dropping their bombs on [[Tokyo, Japan|Tokyo]] and four other Japanese cities.<ref name=AFLink_20081202/> This raid was the first good news that the Americans had from the [[Pacific War|Pacific front]].
Lacking the fuel to make a safe landing after the raid, Jones bailed out over [[China]], where he was assisted by the Chinese people in evading capture. He received the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] for his participation as a flight commander in the planning, training and completion of the mission. After escaping capture, Jones was flown to India, where he spent three months with the [[22d Expeditionary Air Refueling Squadron|22nd Bomb Squadron]] flying further B-25 missions against the Japanese.
===North Africa and Stalag Luft III=== [[File:Sagan harry-3.jpg|thumb|left|Scene of the "Harry" tunnel in Stalag Luft III.]] In September 1942, Jones was assigned to the new [[319th Bombardment Group]], preparing for combat in [[North Africa Campaign|North Africa]]. He was assigned to develop low-level bombing tactics and techniques due to his experience with the Doolittle project and his belief in low-level bombing tactics. On December 4, 1942, he was shot down over [[Bizerte]], North Africa, and spent two and a half years as a [[prisoner of war]] in [[Stalag Luft III]].<ref name=AFbio/> As a result of his constant agitation and harassment of the enemy, he was selected for the "escape committee" by fellow prisoners. The committee reviewed escape plans and directed escapes.<ref name=AFbio/> Jones led the digging team on tunnel "Harry" used in the ''Great Escape'', chronicled in the [[Paul Brickhill]]'s [[The Great Escape (book)|autobiographical book]], and portrayed in the [[The Great Escape (film)|1963 film]].<ref name=ArizonaStarDaily_Sottosanti_20081130> {{cite news |accessdate=December 2, 2008 |url= http://www.azstarnet.com/allheadlines/269556.php |title=Tokyo raider 'Davey' Jones, WWII hero, dies in Tucson |first=Danielle |last=Sottosanti |work=Arizona Daily Star |date=November 30, 2008}}</ref> After his liberation in April 1945, Jones was commended for leadership among his fellow prisoners.<ref name=AFbio/>
==Post-World War II== In July 1946, Jones was assigned as an air inspector at Headquarters [[Air Training Command]]. He followed this with attendance at the Armed Forces Staff College, which he completed in 1948. During this time, the [[U.S. Army Air Forces]] was disestablished and his commission was transferred to the newly established [[United States Air Force]]. He then served as Director of War Plans at Headquarters [[Tactical Air Command]] at [[Langley AFB]], Virginia, followed by an assignment as Director of Combat Operations for the [[Ninth Air Force]]; then as Commander of the [[47th Bombardment Group]], until February 1952.
He was then the commander of the [[47th Bombardment Wing]] (a [[B-45 Tornado]] jetbomber wing) at [[Langley Air Force Base]], Virginia and at [[RAF Sculthorpe]], England until July 1955.<ref name=AFbio/>
===Test pilot=== [[File:B-58 Hustler.jpg|thumb|right|<center>B-58 Hustler</center>]] Jones began working in [[research and development]] in 1956 when he was the Deputy Chief of Staff for Operations for the [[Air Proving Ground Command]] at [[Eglin Air Force Base]], Florida. His experience in bombardment-type aircraft and previous command staff assignments in research and development resulted in his being selected director of the [[B-58 Hustler|B-58]] Test Force, organized in February 1958 at [[Carswell Air Force Base]], Texas. The B-58 Hustler was the first operational jet [[bomber]] capable of Mach 2 [[supersonic]] flight. During this time, Jones continued to maintain his flight status in the B-58, [[F-102 Delta Dagger|TF-102]], and [[T-33 Shooting Star|T-33]] aircraft; participating in design speed dashes, low-level penetrations, night, weather, formation and inflight refueling missions. He had more supersonic time testing the [[B-58 Hustler|B-58]] than any senior U.S. Air Force pilot.
In September 1960, he became vice commander of the Wright Air Development Division at [[Wright-Patterson Air Force Base]], Ohio. In October 1961, he was named program manager of the [[GAM-87]] "Skybolt" at [[Air Force Systems Command]]'s Aeronautical Systems Division. When that project was cancelled, he became ASD deputy for systems management and later vice commander.
In August 1964, he became deputy chief of staff for systems at Headquarters [[Air Force Systems Command]] at [[Andrews Air Force Base]], Maryland, which had responsibility for all USAF research, development, and weapon system acquisition.
===NASA=== In December 1964, Jones became Deputy Assistant Administrator for Manned Space Flight with the [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] (NASA).<ref name=NASA_part2a/> In July 1965, he was given responsibility for development of the [[S-IVB]] Orbital Workshop and spent-stage experiment support module (SSESM) — a concept of "in-orbit" conversion of a spent S-IVB stage to a shelter.<ref name=NASA_part2a/> In August 1965, he took on the additional duties as of the Saturn/Apollo Applications (SAA) Acting Director.<ref name=NASA_part2a>{{cite web|accessdate=December 3, 2008 |url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4011/part2a.htm |title=PART II: Apollo Application Program - August 1965 to December 1966 |work=SP-4011 Skylab: A Chronology |publisher=[[NASA]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041113023044/https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4011/part2a.htm|archivedate=November 13, 2004}}</ref> Then, in May 1967, he assumed duties as commander of the [[Air Force Eastern Test Range]], [[Patrick AFB]] and [[Cape Canaveral AFS|Cape Kennedy AFS]], Florida.
==Retirement; death== Jones retired at the rank of [[Major general (United States)|Major General]] on May 31, 1973. He was one of five Doolittle Raiders who later became [[general officer]]s;<ref name=Joyce>{{cite web|accessdate=December 6, 2008 |url=http://www.doolittleraider.com/ |first=Todd |last=Joyce |title=The Doolittle Tokyo Raiders}}</ref> the others are [[Jimmy Doolittle|James H. Doolittle]], John A. Hilger, Everett W. Holstrom, and [[Richard A. Knobloch]].
Jones died on November 25, 2008, at age 94, at his home in [[Tucson, Arizona]].<ref name=Tuscon_Obit>{{cite news|accessdate=December 2, 2008 |url=http://www.legacy.com/TUCSON/Obituaries.asp?Page=LifeStory&PersonID=120858836 |title=Obituary: Major General David M. Jones |publisher=Tucson.com}}</ref> He was preceded in death by his first wife Anita Maddox Jones, and survived by his wife Janna-Neen Johnson-Dingell-Cunningham-Jones, daughter (Jere Jones Yeager), two sons (David Jones and Jim Jones) and a stepdaughter (Ann-Eve Grace Dingell-Cunningham) .<ref name=Tuscon_Obit/> At the time of his death, out of the eighty men who participated in the Doolittle Raid, there were ten survivors.<ref name=AFLink_20081202/>
==Awards and decorations== Major General Jones' military decorations and awards include: {| |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=Air Force Distinguished Service ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Air Force Distinguished Service Medal]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=Legion of Merit ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Legion of Merit]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=Purple Heart ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Purple Heart]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=1|type=oak|ribbon=Distinguished Flying Cross ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] with [[oak leaf cluster]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=Air Medal ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Air Medal]] |- |{{ribbon devices|number=1|type=oak|ribbon=Air Force Commendation ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Air Force Commendation Medal]] with oak leaf cluster |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=NasaDisRib.gif|width=60}} |[[NASA Distinguished Service Medal]], the highest honor conferred by NASA |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=USA - NASA Excep Rib.png|width=60}} |[[NASA Exceptional Service Medal]] with device |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=Prisoner of War Medal ribbon.svg|width=60}} |[[Prisoner of War Medal]] (awarded retroactively post-USAF retirement) |- |{{ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=noribbon.svg|width=60}} |Yum Hwei (China) |} <ref name=AFbio>{{cite web|accessdate=May 22, 2009 |url=http://www.af.mil/AboutUs/Biographies/Display/tabid/225/Article/106591/major-general-david-m-jones.aspx|title=Biographies: Major General David M. Jones |work=The official website of the U.S. Air Force |publisher=United States Air Force}}</ref><ref name=NASA_DSM>{{cite web |accessdate=December 2, 2008 |url=http://nasapeople.nasa.gov/awards/nasamedals.htm |title=Agency Honor Awards |publisher=[[NASA]]}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Biography|United States Air Force}} *[[Jimmy Doolittle]] *[[NASA]] *[[Test pilot]] *''[[Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo]]'', 1944 film on the Doolittle Raid, starring [[Spencer Tracy]]

Jones |work=Air Force Link |publisher=United States Air Force |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080709170917/http://www.af.mil/bios/bio.asp?bioID=5972 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate=July 9, 2008 }}

Tabbystone Press, 2012. {{ISBN|978-0-9850612-0-3}}. *{{cite web|accessdate=December 2, 2008 |url=http://www.doolittleraider.com/raiders/jonesDM.htm |title=David M. Jones, 0-22482, Major General, Pilot Crew 3 |first=Todd |last=Joyce |publisher=The Doolittle Tokyo Raiders}}
==External links== *{{cite web|accessdate=December 2, 2008 |url=http://www.usafa.af.mil/df/dflib/SL3/americans/jones.cfm?catname=Dean%20of%20Faculty |title=USAFA Stalag Luft III — Majs. David M. Jones and William C. Beckham |work=American Personalities |publisher=United States Air Force Academy, United States Air Force |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109131942/http://www.usafa.af.mil/df/dflib/SL3/americans/jones.cfm?catname=Dean%20of%20Faculty |archivedate=January 9, 2009 }} * {{YouTube|title="The Real Virgil Hilts"|lvJD3HUDYj4}} {{Authority control}}
